verb.description: (typically of a person) fall suddenly, clumsily, or headlong.
examples: she pitched forward, tumbling down the remaining stairs

verb.description: Perform acrobatic or gymnastic exercises, typically handsprings and somersaults in the air.
Understand the meaning or hidden implication of (a situation)
Clean (castings, gemstones, etc.) in a tumbling barrel.

examples: I took a tumble in the nettles

noun.description: A handspring, somersault in the air, or other acrobatic feat.
A friendly sign of recognition, acknowledgment, or interest.
examples: not a soul gave him a tumble

origin: Middle English (as a verb, also in the sense dance with contortions): from Middle Low German tummelen; compare with Old English tumbian to dance. The sense was probably influenced by Old French tomber to fall. The noun, first in the sense tangled mass, dates from the mid 17th century.
